parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions can be taken to mitigate the impacts of roads on amphibian populations.
[Statement 2]: Closing roads during seasonal amphibian migration has been found to be an effective protective measure.
[Statement 3]: Studies in Germany showed that large numbers of amphibians were protected from death during breeding migrations at road closure sites.
[Statement 4]: Large numbers of amphibians were also protected from death during breeding migrations at road closure sites with assisted crossings and barrier fences.
[Statement 5]: Installing barrier fencing along roads is an effective measure to protect amphibians.
[Statement 6]: Seven of eight studies in Germany, Canada and the USA found that barrier fencing with culverts decreased amphibian road deaths.
[Statement 7]: The effectiveness of barrier fencing is dependent on the fence length and material.
[Statement 8]: Barriers must be at least 0.6 m high to prevent some amphibian species from climbing over the barriers.
[Statement 9]: Installing culverts or tunnels as road crossings for amphibians has shown significant success.
[Statement 10]: Six of seven studies in Canada, Germany, Italy, Hungary and the USA found that installing culverts or tunnels significantly decreased amphibian road deaths.
[Statement 11]: The installation of culverts or tunnels was most effective when barrier fencing was also installed.
[Statement 12]: Fifteen of 24 studies found that culverts and tunnels were used by amphibians.
[Statement 13]: Amphibian usage rates of culverts and tunnels were found to be 15-85% of amphibians or involved 3-15 species.
[Statement 14]: Restoring habitat connectivity can be an effective measure for protecting amphibians.
[Statement 15]: A study in Italy showed that raising a road on a viaduct to restore connectivity between two wetlands significantly decreased deaths of migrating amphibians.
[Statement 16]: Warning signage for motorists has been tested but showed limited effectiveness in protecting amphibians.
[Statement 17]: One study in the UK found that despite warning signs and human assistance, over 500 toads were still killed on some roads.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What actions can be taken to mitigate the impacts of roads on amphibian populations?
_claude-sonnet-4__How do different partial harvesting methods in USA forests compare to clearcutting in their impact on salamander populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on studies in USA forests, different partial harvesting methods show varied impacts on salamander populations compared to clearcutting.
[Statement 2]: A meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America found that partial harvest methods resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting.
[Statement 3]: Partial harvest methods include harvesting groups or individual trees, thinning, and shelterwood harvesting.
[Statement 4]: Three studies in the USA found that shelterwood harvesting resulted in higher, similar, or initially higher and then similar salamander abundance compared to clearcutting.
[Statement 5]: Three studies found that harvesting trees in small groups did not result in higher amphibian or salamander abundance when compared to clearcutting.
[Statement 6]: Two studies in the USA found that leaving a low density of trees during leave-tree harvesting did not result in higher salamander abundance compared to clearcutting.
[Statement 7]: Four studies in the USA comparing amphibians in thinned to clearcut forests found either higher amphibian abundance, a less negative overall response, or mixed effects on abundance.
[Statement 8]: The effects of thinning on amphibian abundance depended on species, life stage, and time since harvest.
[Statement 9]: One study found that emigrating salamanders used thinned forest significantly more than clearcuts.
[Statement 10]: When compared to unharvested areas, all partial harvesting methods showed negative impacts on salamanders.
[Statement 11]: Compared to unharvested areas, harvesting trees in small groups significantly decreased salamander abundance and changed species composition.
[Statement 12]: In two of three studies, shelterwood harvesting decreased salamander abundance and changed species composition compared to unharvested areas.
[Statement 13]: Compared to unharvested areas, leave-tree harvesting decreased salamander abundance and changed species composition.
[Statement 14]: Thinning showed mixed effects on salamanders depending on the amphibian species and time since harvest when compared to unharvested areas.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the potential benefits and harms of controlling fish populations to protect amphibians?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Controlling fish populations to protect amphibians shows several potential benefits and some documented harms.
[Statement 2]: Three studies found that eliminating fish using rotenone increased numbers of amphibian species, abundance and recruitment.
[Statement 3]: Three studies found that eliminating fish using rotenone increased newt populations.
[Statement 4]: One review found that fish control, which included using rotenone, increased breeding success for four amphibian species.
[Statement 5]: Four studies found that removing fish by catching them significantly increased the abundance of salamanders or frogs.
[Statement 6]: Four studies found that removing fish by catching them increased the recruitment, survival and population growth rate of the cascades frog.
[Statement 7]: One controlled study found that excluding fish using a barrier increased weight gain of axolotls.
[Statement 8]: Two replicated studies found when rotenone was applied, many frogs died.
[Statement 9]: Two replicated studies found when rotenone was applied, a small number of newts showed symptoms of negative effects.
[Statement 10]: One before-and-after study found that fish control had no significant effect on great crested newt populations.
[Statement 11]: One before-and-after study found that fish remained or returned within a few years after control efforts.
[Statement 12]: One replicated, before-and-after study found that fish control did not increase green toad breeding success.
[Statement 13]: One replicated, before-and-after study found that fish were soon reintroduced after a control effort.

[Statement 1]: Evidence from action documents shows multiple forms of public engagement in amphibian conservation with measurable outcomes in Europe and the USA.
[Statement 2]: Citizen science programs demonstrate substantial public participation in amphibian conservation.
[Statement 3]: Studies in Canada, the UK, and the USA found that amphibian data collection projects engaged between 100 and 10,506 volunteers.
[Statement 4]: Amphibian data collection projects were active in 16 to 17 states in the USA.
[Statement 5]: Volunteers in the UK and USA undertook 412 surveys for amphibian conservation.
[Statement 6]: Volunteers surveyed between 121 and 7,872 sites for amphibians in the UK and USA.
[Statement 7]: Volunteers swabbed almost 6,000 amphibians in studies across the UK and USA.
[Statement 8]: Volunteers submitted thousands of amphibian records across studies in the UK and USA.
[Statement 9]: Habitat management involving volunteers shows conservation effectiveness.
[Statement 10]: Before-and-after studies in Estonia and Taiwan found that habitat management with volunteer participation increased natterjack toad and Taipei frog populations.
[Statement 11]: Studies in Estonia, the USA, and the UK found that between eight and 41,000 volunteers were engaged in aquatic and terrestrial habitat restoration programmes for amphibians.
[Statement 12]: Individual habitat restoration programmes for amphibians restored up to 1,023 ponds.
[Statement 13]: Individual habitat restoration programmes for amphibians restored over 11,500 square kilometers of habitat.
[Statement 14]: Public awareness campaigns demonstrated public reach and some positive conservation outcomes.
[Statement 15]: Studies in Estonia and the UK found that raising public awareness, along with other interventions, increased the numbers of natterjack toads.
[Statement 16]: Raising public awareness, combined with other interventions, created 1,023 ponds for amphibians in Estonia and the UK.
[Statement 17]: Awareness campaigns in Panama and the UK reached over 50,000 members of the public each year.
[Statement 18]: Awareness campaigns in Panama and the UK trained 1,016 people at 57 events over four years.
[Statement 19]: Education programmes show improvement in public knowledge and achieve conservation outcomes.
[Statement 20]: Studies in Germany, Mexico, Zimbabwe, and the USA found that education programmes increased the amphibian knowledge of students, boatmen, and their tourists.
[Statement 21]: A study in Taiwan found that education programmes about wetlands and amphibians, along with other interventions, doubled a population of Taipei frogs.
[Statement 22]: Road assistance programs demonstrate substantial volunteer engagement despite having mixed conservation outcomes.
[Statement 23]: Studies in Germany, the UK, and Italy found that large numbers of amphibians were moved across roads by patrols, ranging from 7,532 toads to half a million annually.
[Statement 24]: In the UK, there were over 400 patrols to assist amphibians crossing roads.
[Statement 25]: In the UK, 71 road patrols spent an average of 90 person-hours moving toads.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence for the effectiveness of engaging the public in amphibian conservation efforts in Europe and the USA?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: According to global reviews of amphibian translocation efforts, 65% of amphibian translocations that could be assessed resulted in established breeding populations or substantial recruitment to the adult population.
[Statement 2]: A review of release programs for captive-bred or head-started amphibians found that 41% of programs showed evidence of breeding in the wild for multiple generations.
[Statement 3]: A review of release programs for captive-bred or head-started amphibians found that 29% of programs showed some evidence of breeding.
[Statement 4]: A review of release programs for captive-bred or head-started amphibians found that 12% of programs showed evidence of survival following release.
[Statement 5]: For head-started amphibians specifically, six of 10 studies found that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding populations.
[Statement 6]: For head-started amphibians specifically, six of 10 studies found that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles increased frog or toad populations.
[Statement 7]: Two studies on head-started amphibians found mixed results, with breeding populations established in 12 of 17 studies reviewed.
[Statement 8]: Two studies on head-started amphibians found mixed results, with breeding populations established at two of four sites.
[Statement 9]: Studies indicated that translocations of over 1,000 animals were more successful.
[Statement 10]: The success of amphibian translocation was not related to whether animals came from wild or captive sources.
[Statement 11]: The success of amphibian translocation was not related to the life-stage of the animals.
[Statement 12]: The success of amphibian translocation was not related to the continent where the translocation occurred.
[Statement 13]: The success of amphibian translocation was not related to the reason for the translocation.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the overall success rates for establishing new amphibian populations through translocation or the release of captive-bred individuals?
_claude-sonnet-4__As an alternative to direct antifungal treatment of amphibians, what environmental management actions can reduce the threat of chytridiomycosis?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several environmental management actions have been identified as alternatives to direct antifungal treatment for reducing chytridiomycosis threats to amphibians.
[Statement 2]: Adding salt to ponds has shown promise for reducing chytridiomycosis threats.
[Statement 3]: One study in Australia found that a population of green and golden bell frogs remained free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months following salt addition to a pond containing the chytrid fungus.
[Statement 4]: Removing the chytrid fungus from ponds through pond drying and fungicidal treatment has been tested.
[Statement 5]: One study in Mallorca found that removing the chytrid fungus from ponds through pond drying and fungicidal treatment reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 6]: Equipment sterilization when moving between amphibian sites is recommended to prevent disease spread.
[Statement 7]: No direct evidence exists for the effectiveness of equipment sterilization on disease transmission between amphibian populations.
[Statement 8]: Studies show that while Virkon S disinfectant does not affect amphibian survival, bleach significantly reduces the survival of tadpoles.
[Statement 9]: The use of gloves when handling amphibians is practiced to prevent disease spread.
[Statement 10]: Latex, vinyl, and nitrile gloves have been found to cause deaths in various tadpole species.
[Statement 11]: Other proposed environmental approaches include using zooplankton to remove chytrid zoospores.
[Statement 12]: Other proposed environmental approaches include preventing heavy usage or excluding wildfowl from aquatic habitat.
[Statement 13]: No evidence exists yet for the effectiveness of using zooplankton to remove chytrid zoospores.
[Statement 14]: No evidence exists yet for the effectiveness of preventing heavy usage or excluding wildfowl from aquatic habitat.

[Statement 1]: Three studies in the USA found that understory removal using herbicide had no effect on amphibian abundance.
[Statement 2]: Three studies in the USA found that understory removal using herbicide had some negative effects on amphibian abundance.
[Statement 3]: A study in Canada found that following logging, American toad abundance was similar in stands with herbicide treatment and planting compared to stands left to regenerate naturally.
[Statement 4]: A study in Canada found that following logging, wood frogs were lower in stands with herbicide treatment and planting compared to stands left to regenerate naturally.
[Statement 5]: One study in the USA found that the number of amphibian species was significantly higher in plots with mechanical understory reduction compared to plots without mechanical understory reduction.
[Statement 6]: One study in the USA found that amphibian abundance was not significantly higher in plots with mechanical understory reduction compared to plots without mechanical understory reduction.
[Statement 7]: A study in the USA found that areas burned in combination with herbicide application had similar combined reptile and amphibian species richness and diversity compared to areas managed by burning alone, herbicide application alone, or left unmanaged.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__When managing understory vegetation in US forests, how does the effectiveness of herbicide use compare to mechanical removal for amphibian populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence suggests mixed effectiveness of legal and regulatory frameworks for amphibian conservation.
[Statement 2]: For species protection laws, three reviews in the Netherlands and UK found that legal protection of amphibian species was not effective at protecting populations during development.
[Statement 3]: The number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued over 10 years increased to over 600 in England and Wales.
[Statement 4]: One replicated site comparison study in the UK found that populations of natterjack toads were better protected at sites with a statutory level of habitat protection than at sites outside protected areas.
[Statement 5]: A before-and-after study showed that a common frog population increased but common toads decreased following pond protection during development.
[Statement 6]: For trade regulation, one review found that legislation to reduce trade in two frog species resulted in the recovery of over-exploited populations.
[Statement 7]: One study in South Africa found that the number of permits issued for scientific and educational use of amphibians increased from 1987 to 1990.
[Statement 8]: Three studies in Denmark, Sweden and Taiwan found that payments to farmers created amphibian breeding habitat or increased frog or toad populations.
[Statement 9]: A second study in Taiwan found that payments did not maintain green tree frog habitat.
[Statement 10]: One replicated site comparison study in the Netherlands found that ditches managed under agri-environment schemes had higher numbers of amphibian species and higher abundance than ditches managed conventionally.
[Statement 11]: Studies from the USA showed limited effectiveness for mitigation requirements.
[Statement 12]: Four studies reported that requiring mitigation of impacts to wetlands did not prevent loss of wetland area, as the total area restored or created was less than the area destroyed.
[Statement 13]: Eight studies reported compliance issues with mitigation requirements.
[Statement 14]: Five studies found that the total area of wetlands conserved was less than the area required in permits.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What does the evidence suggest about the effectiveness of legal and regulatory frameworks, such as species protection laws or financial incentive schemes, for amphibian conservation?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Livestock grazing on agricultural lands has mixed documented effects on amphibian habitats and populations.
[Statement 2]: Three replicated, site comparison studies in the USA showed that excluding livestock from streams or ponds did not increase the numbers of amphibian species or the overall abundance of amphibians.
[Statement 3]: Two studies found that the abundance of green frogs and/or American toads was higher with livestock grazing.
[Statement 4]: A randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that excluding cattle from ponds did not increase the numbers of eggs of Columbia spotted frogs.
[Statement 5]: A randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that excluding cattle from ponds did not increase the larval survival of Columbia spotted frogs.
[Statement 6]: Three replicated, site comparison studies in the USA found that excluding livestock from streams or ponds increased amphibian larval abundance.
[Statement 7]: Three replicated, site comparison studies in the USA found that excluding livestock from streams or ponds increased the abundance of green frog metamorphs.
[Statement 8]: A before-and-after study in the UK found that pond restoration that included livestock exclusion increased pond use by breeding natterjack toads.
[Statement 9]: Livestock exclusion studies document impacts on wetland vegetation that may affect amphibian habitat quality.
[Statement 10]: Marshes and pools fenced to exclude cattle for periods ranging from 1 to 30 years showed increased vegetation abundance and height around pond margins.
[Statement 11]: Increased vegetation abundance and height around pond margins could provide improved amphibian habitat structure.
[Statement 12]: Excluding cattle allowed better growth of mangrove vegetation in brackish and saline swamps.
[Statement 13]: The effects of livestock grazing on amphibians are species-specific and context-dependent.
[Statement 14]: Some amphibian species benefit from grazing.
[Statement 15]: Other amphibian species benefit from livestock exclusion.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of livestock grazing on agricultural lands for amphibian habitats and populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several treatments are available for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 2]: Antifungal treatments show the most promise for treating amphibians with chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 3]: Twelve of 16 studies found that antifungal treatment cured or increased the survival of amphibians with chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 4]: Four studies found antifungal treatments did not cure chytridiomycosis but reduced infection levels.
[Statement 5]: The antifungal Itraconazole was specifically effective against chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 6]: Six of eight studies found Itraconazole cured amphibians of chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 7]: One study found Itraconazole reduced infection levels of chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 8]: One study showed mixed effects for Itraconazole as a treatment for chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 9]: Six studies found that specific fungicides caused death or other negative side effects in amphibians.
[Statement 10]: Temperature treatment is another effective option for treating amphibians with chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 11]: Four of five studies found that increasing enclosure or water temperature to 30-37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 12]: One study found that heat treatment at 30-35°C for 36 hours did not cure northern leopard frogs of chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 13]: Antibacterial treatments for chytridiomycosis have shown mixed results.
[Statement 14]: Two studies found that treatment with chloramphenicol antibiotic ointment or solution cured green tree frogs and one Archey's frog of chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 15]: One study found that the antibacterial trimethoprim-sulfadiazine increased survival time but did not cure blue-and-yellow poison dart frogs of chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 16]: Antifungal skin bacteria or peptides show limited effectiveness against chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 17]: Three of four studies found that adding antifungal bacteria to amphibian skin did not reduce the infection rate or death from chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 18]: One study found that adding antifungal bacteria to amphibian skin prevented infection and death from chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 19]: Three studies found that adding antifungal bacteria to amphibian skin reduced weight loss in infected amphibians.
[Statement 20]: Treatment with antimicrobial skin peptides did not significantly increase the survival of common toads with chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 21]: Environmental treatments for chytridiomycosis include adding salt to ponds.
[Statement 22]: One study found that adding salt to a pond kept a population of green and golden bell frogs free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months.
[Statement 23]: Pond drying and fungicidal treatment of toads reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 24]: Vaccination with formalin-killed chytrid fungus did not significantly reduce infection rate or mortality from chytridiomycosis.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What treatments are available for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis and how effective are they?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on North American studies, both wetland restoration and wetland creation have shown positive outcomes for amphibian conservation.
[Statement 2]: Ten site comparison studies in Canada and the USA found that amphibian abundance, numbers of species, and species composition were generally similar between restored and natural wetlands.
[Statement 3]: Eight of the ten site comparison studies showed similar outcomes for amphibian populations between restored and natural wetlands.
[Statement 4]: Two of the ten site comparison studies found lower species numbers or different species composition in restored wetlands compared to natural wetlands.
[Statement 5]: Seven of nine studies in Canada, Taiwan and the USA found that wetland restoration increased numbers of amphibian species.
[Statement 6]: Following wetland restoration, breeding populations of amphibians were found to establish in some cases.
[Statement 7]: One global review found that in 89% of cases, restored and created wetlands had similar or higher amphibian abundance or numbers of species compared to natural wetlands.
[Statement 8]: Five site comparison studies in the USA found that created wetlands had similar numbers of amphibian species, amphibian abundance or communities compared to natural wetlands.
[Statement 9]: Two studies found that created wetlands had fewer amphibian species or lower abundance and different communities compared to natural wetlands.
[Statement 10]: Five studies in Kenya and the USA investigating colonization of created wetlands found that four to 15 amphibian species used or colonized the new wetlands.
[Statement 11]: A global review and site comparison studies found that the numbers of amphibian species and abundance was higher or similar in created wetlands compared to natural wetlands.
[Statement 12]: In 54% of studies reviewed, created wetlands showed higher numbers of amphibian species and abundance compared to natural wetlands.
[Statement 13]: In 35% of studies reviewed, created wetlands showed similar numbers of amphibian species and abundance compared to natural wetlands.
[Statement 14]: One global review and studies in the USA found that created, restored, enhanced and natural wetlands had similar combined reptile and amphibian species richness.
[Statement 15]: The effectiveness of both wetland creation and restoration was influenced by factors including wetland design, vegetation, water levels, and surrounding habitat.
[Statement 16]: The effectiveness of both wetland creation and restoration was influenced by factors including fish presence, distance to source wetlands, wetland size, proximity to source ponds, and seasonality.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__For amphibian conservation in North America, how do the outcomes of creating new wetlands compare to restoring existing wetlands?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Prescribed fire has varied effects on amphibian populations in US forest and grassland habitats.
[Statement 2]: In grassland habitats, annual prescribed fires decreased the numbers of amphibian species.
[Statement 3]: In grassland habitats, annual prescribed fires decreased amphibian abundance.
[Statement 4]: A study in the USA found that spring burns decreased salamander abundance.
[Statement 5]: A study in the USA found that autumn or winter burns did not decrease salamander abundance.
[Statement 6]: In forest habitats, the impacts of prescribed fire are more complex, with studies showing mixed results.
[Statement 7]: Eight of fourteen studies found no effect of prescribed forest fires on amphibian abundance or the number of species.
[Statement 8]: Four studies on prescribed forest fires found mixed effects on amphibians depending on the species, the year, or the season of the burn.
[Statement 9]: Three studies found that prescribed fires increased amphibian abundance or the number of amphibian species.
[Statement 10]: One study found that amphibian abundance decreased with prescribed fires.
[Statement 11]: The amount of time that has passed since a fire also influenced amphibian populations.
[Statement 12]: Two studies found that with time since a prescribed forest fire, the numbers of amphibian species and abundance either increased or the abundance decreased.
[Statement 13]: A study in the USA found that spotted salamander hatching success increased following a prescribed forest fire.
[Statement 14]: In wetland environments, one study in Australia found that burned areas had a similar abundance of reptiles and amphibians when compared to unburned areas.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the documented impacts of using prescribed fire on amphibian populations in US forest and grassland habitats?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence on removing invasive predators to benefit native amphibians shows mixed results depending on the predator type and removal method.
[Statement 2]: Fish removal by catching has moderate evidence of effectiveness.
[Statement 3]: Four studies in the USA found that removing fish by catching significantly increased the abundance of salamanders or frogs.
[Statement 4]: The removal of fish by catching also increased recruitment, survival, and the population growth rate of the cascades frog.
[Statement 5]: A before-and-after study in the UK found that fish control had no significant effect on great crested newt populations.
[Statement 6]: The UK study also found that fish remained or returned within a few years after control efforts.
[Statement 7]: A replicated study in Sweden found that fish control did not increase green toad breeding success.
[Statement 8]: In the Swedish study, fish were soon reintroduced after control efforts.
[Statement 9]: Fish removal using rotenone shows stronger evidence of effectiveness.
[Statement 10]: Three studies in Sweden, the UK, and the USA found that eliminating fish using rotenone increased numbers of amphibian species, abundance, and recruitment or newt populations.
[Statement 11]: One review found that fish control including rotenone increased breeding success for four amphibian species.
[Statement 12]: Two studies found that when rotenone was applied, many frogs died.
[Statement 13]: The same two studies also found that some newts showed negative effects from the application of rotenone.
[Statement 14]: Invasive amphibian removal shows positive evidence for benefiting native amphibians.
[Statement 15]: One study in the USA found that removing American bullfrogs significantly increased California red-legged frog populations.
[Statement 16]: The removal of American bullfrogs also increased the range of California red-legged frogs with leopard frogs.
[Statement 17]: One study found that removing invasive Cuban tree frogs increased the abundance of squirrel tree frogs and green tree frogs.
[Statement 18]: There is limited evidence for the effectiveness of mammalian predator control.
[Statement 19]: One study in New Zealand found that controlling rats had no significant effect on Hochstetter's frog numbers.
[Statement 20]: The same New Zealand study noted that predator-proof enclosures showed higher survival rates for other frog species.
[Statement 21]: There is no evidence found for the effectiveness of removing non-native crayfish.
[Statement 22]: A single study in Mexico showed that excluding fish with barriers increased axolotl weight gain.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the state of evidence on the effectiveness of removing various types of invasive predators to benefit native amphibians?
_claude-sonnet-4__How does the success of reintroduction programs using captive-bred amphibians differ for Mallorcan midwife toads in Mallorca compared to green and golden bell frogs in Australia?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The success of reintroduction programs using captive-bred amphibians differs significantly between Mallorcan midwife toads in Mallorca and green and golden bell frogs in Australia.
[Statement 2]: Captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads released as tadpoles, toadlets or adults established breeding populations at 38%, 80% or 100% of sites.
[Statement 3]: Captive-bred green and golden bell frogs released mainly as tadpoles did not establish breeding populations.
[Statement 4]: Captive-bred green and golden bell frogs only established stable breeding populations following one of four release programmes.
[Statement 5]: Only a small proportion of captive-bred green and golden bell frogs released as tadpoles survived at least 13 months after release.
[Statement 6]: The captive breeding itself was successful for Mallorcan midwife toads.
[Statement 7]: Mallorcan midwife toads produced eggs that were raised to metamorphs or toadlets successfully in captivity.
[Statement 8]: Survival to metamorphosis for captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads reached 85%.
[Statement 9]: Both Mallorcan midwife toads and green and golden bell frogs experienced some concerns in captive breeding programs.
[Statement 10]: Mallorcan midwife toads bred in captivity for nine or more generations showed slower tadpole development.
[Statement 11]: Mallorcan midwife toads bred in captivity for nine or more generations showed a reduction in one predator defence trait.
[Statement 12]: Mallorcan midwife toads bred in captivity for nine or more generations showed decreased genetic diversity.
[Statement 13]: Reintroduced populations of Mallorcan midwife toads maintained predator defences.
[Statement 14]: Reintroduced populations of Mallorcan midwife toads had reduced genetic diversity.

[Statement 1]: In Australian captive frog breeding programs, hormone treatments and artificial fertilization show distinct patterns of success and challenges.
[Statement 2]: Hormone treatment to induce sperm and egg release in frogs shows mixed effectiveness.
[Statement 3]: Studies found that hormone treatment of female amphibians had varying results, with 30-71% of females producing viable eggs following treatment.
[Statement 4]: In hormone-treated female amphibians, egg production depends on the combination, amount, or number of doses of hormones.
[Statement 5]: The success of hormone treatment for frog breeding varies significantly by species and hormone combinations.
[Statement 6]: Some studies show successful frog breeding in captivity using hormone treatments, while other studies show no breeding results.
[Statement 7]: Australian studies on artificial fertilization demonstrate that success depends on the type and number of hormone doses used to stimulate egg production.
[Statement 8]: One Australian study showed that 55% of frog eggs were artificially fertilized, but the fertilized eggs soon died.
[Statement 9]: A critical challenge in frog breeding is that artificial fertilization can achieve fertilization but faces significant mortality issues in early development.
[Statement 10]: The overall success of Australian frog captive breeding varies.
[Statement 11]: Studies have found that some frog species, or 17-50% of captive populations, reproduce successfully in captivity.
[Statement 12]: Other captive frog species prove difficult to maintain or raise to adults.
[Statement 13]: In Australia, captive-bred green and golden bell frogs released mainly as tadpoles did not establish breeding populations in most cases.
[Statement 14]: Stable breeding populations of green and golden bell frogs were established following only one of four release programmes in Australia.
[Statement 15]: Frog breeding programs in Australia face ongoing challenges in both the breeding process and post-breeding survival of the animals.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In Australian captive breeding programs, how do artificial fertilization and hormone treatments compare in their success and challenges for frogs?
_claude-sonnet-4__As an alternative to creating new ponds, what species augmentation techniques can be used to establish or increase amphibian populations at a site?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several species augmentation techniques can be used to establish or increase amphibian populations as alternatives to pond creation.
[Statement 2]: Translocation of amphibians has shown success, with 35 of 54 amphibian translocations resulting in established breeding populations or substantial recruitment to the adult population.
[Statement 3]: Translocations of over 1,000 animals were found to be more successful.
[Statement 4]: The success of amphibian translocations was not related to whether the animals were wild or captive-sourced, the animal's life-stage, the continent, or the reason for the translocation.
[Statement 5]: Release of captive-bred amphibians is another species augmentation technique.
[Statement 6]: 41% of release programmes for captive-bred amphibians showed evidence of breeding in the wild for multiple generations.
[Statement 7]: 29% of release programmes for captive-bred amphibians showed some evidence of breeding.
[Statement 8]: 12% of release programmes for captive-bred amphibians showed evidence of survival following release.
[Statement 9]: In some studies, captive-bred frogs released as tadpoles, juveniles or adults established populations or stable breeding populations at 88-100% of sites.
[Statement 10]: In some cases, captive-bred frogs colonized new sites after being released.
[Statement 11]: Head-starting amphibians involves raising amphibians from eggs in captivity before release.
[Statement 12]: Six of 10 studies found that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding populations.
[Statement 13]: Six of 10 studies found that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles increased existing populations.
[Statement 14]: Head-started amphibians showed greater survival to metamorphosis compared to wild animals.
[Statement 15]: Head-started amphibians showed a larger size at metamorphosis compared to wild animals.
[Statement 16]: Supporting captive breeding techniques include hormone treatment to induce sperm and egg release.
[Statement 17]: Hormone treatment resulted in successful breeding in captivity in nine of 10 studies for male amphibians.
[Statement 18]: Hormone treatment to induce egg release had mixed results for female amphibians.
[Statement 19]: Artificial fertilization can be used as a captive breeding technique.
[Statement 20]: The success of artificial fertilization in amphibians depends on the type and number of hormone doses used to stimulate egg production.
[Statement 21]: Captive breeding of amphibians has been successful.
[Statement 22]: 23 of 33 studies found that amphibians produced eggs in captivity.

[Statement 1]: Road closures during seasonal amphibian migration have demonstrated effectiveness.
[Statement 2]: Two studies in Germany found that large numbers of amphibians were protected from death during breeding migrations at road closure sites.
[Statement 3]: Large numbers of amphibians were protected from death during breeding migrations at road closure sites with assisted crossings and barrier fences.
[Statement 4]: Physical interventions to protect migrating amphibians show mixed effectiveness depending on implementation.
[Statement 5]: Barrier fencing with culverts decreased amphibian road deaths in seven of eight studies across Germany, Canada and the USA.
[Statement 6]: The effectiveness of barrier fencing with culverts depends on fence length and material.
[Statement 7]: Barriers have limitations, as they must be at least 0.6 m high to prevent green frogs and leopard frogs from climbing over.
[Statement 8]: Treefrogs and 10% of common toads still climbed over barrier fencing during breeding migrations.
[Statement 9]: Culverts and tunnels show variable success rates for protecting migrating amphibians.
[Statement 10]: Six of seven studies found that installing culverts or tunnels significantly decreased amphibian road deaths.
[Statement 11]: In one study, installing culverts or tunnels was only effective when barrier fencing was also installed.
[Statement 12]: Fifteen of 24 studies found that culverts or tunnels were used by 15-85% of amphibians or by 3-15 species.
[Statement 13]: In a collection of studies, 23-100% of installed culverts or tunnels were used by amphibians.
[Statement 14]: Five studies found that culverts were used by less than 10% of amphibians or were not used at all.
[Statement 15]: The effectiveness of tunnels and culverts was affected by various design factors.
[Statement 16]: Design factors affecting tunnel and culvert use include diameter, length, lighting, substrate, and the presence of water.
[Statement 17]: Wider culverts were used more by amphibians, while long culverts were avoided.
[Statement 18]: Culverts and tunnels with natural substrates were used more by amphibians.
[Statement 19]: One study noted that thousands of amphibians were still killed on roads even with tunnel systems in place.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__To protect migrating amphibians, how do physical interventions like tunnels and barrier fences compare to closing roads during migration seasons?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating new ponds to support toad populations in Europe shows several typical outcomes.
[Statement 2]: For natterjack toads, five before-and-after studies in the UK and Denmark found that pond creation, along with other interventions, significantly increased natterjack toad populations.
[Statement 3]: Pond creation, along with other interventions, maintained or increased natterjack toad populations at 75% of sites.
[Statement 4]: Created ponds had lower natterjack toad tadpole mortality from desiccation compared to natural ponds.
[Statement 5]: Created ponds had higher mortality for natterjack toad tadpoles from predation by invertebrates compared to natural ponds.
[Statement 6]: Two before-and-after studies in Denmark found that pond creation significantly increased green toad populations.
[Statement 7]: A replicated study in Sweden found that green toads used 59% of created ponds.
[Statement 8]: A replicated study in Sweden found that green toads reproduced in 41% of created ponds.
[Statement 9]: Studies in Germany, the UK and USA found that translocated and naturally colonizing toads established breeding populations in created ponds.
[Statement 10]: In one case, translocated and naturally colonizing toads established breeding populations in 33% of created ponds.
[Statement 11]: European studies found that common toads naturally colonized between 29% and 100% of created ponds.
[Statement 12]: Midwife toads reproduced in 16% of created ponds in Switzerland.
[Statement 13]: Pond restoration studies across multiple European countries found that restoration and creation increased the numbers of amphibian species.
[Statement 14]: Pond restoration and creation maintained or increased amphibian populations.
[Statement 15]: Pond restoration and creation increased pond occupancy and the number of ponds with breeding success for amphibians.
[Statement 16]: Restored and created ponds were colonized by one to seven species of amphibians.
[Statement 17]: Between 6% and 65% of restored and created ponds were colonized by amphibians.
[Statement 18]: Thirty-five percent of restored and created ponds were used for amphibian breeding.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the typical outcomes when creating new ponds to support toad populations in Europe?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several alternatives to clearcutting forests have been documented with varying effects on amphibian populations.
[Statement 2]: Patch retention harvesting involves retaining patches of trees rather than removing all vegetation.
[Statement 3]: A study in Canada found that released red-legged frogs did not show significant movement towards retained tree patches.
[Statement 4]: The Canadian study found that large retained tree patches were selected more by red-legged frogs than small patches.
[Statement 5]: The Canadian study also found that red-legged frogs moved out of large retained tree patches less than they moved out of small patches.
[Statement 6]: Thinning trees within forests is an alternative to clearcutting.
[Statement 7]: Five studies in the USA found mixed effects on amphibian abundance from thinning, depending on species and time since harvest.
[Statement 8]: Of the five U.S. studies, two found mixed effects of thinning on abundance, one found that amphibian abundance increased except for ensatina salamanders, one found a negative overall response, and one found that thinning did not affect abundance.
[Statement 9]: A meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America found that partial harvest including thinning decreased salamander populations.
[Statement 10]: When compared to clearcutting, four studies found that two showed higher amphibian abundance in thinned forest, and two found mixed effects on abundance depending on species, life stage and time since harvest.
[Statement 11]: The meta-analysis found that partial harvest resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting.
[Statement 12]: Shelterwood harvesting is an alternative to clearcutting.
[Statement 13]: Three studies in the USA found that compared to clearcutting, shelterwood harvesting resulted in higher, similar or initially higher and then similar salamander abundance.
[Statement 14]: A meta-analysis found that partial harvest including shelterwood harvesting resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting.
[Statement 15]: Two of three studies found that compared to no harvesting, shelterwood harvesting decreased salamander abundance.
[Statement 16]: Two of three studies found that compared to no harvesting, shelterwood harvesting changed salamander species composition.
[Statement 17]: One study found that high volumes of pre-existing downed wood prevented declines in amphibian populations following thinning.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are some alternatives to clearcutting forests, and what are their documented effects on amphibian populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Documented benefits of releasing captive-bred or head-started toads include the successful establishment of breeding populations.
[Statement 2]: Documented benefits of releasing captive-bred or head-started toads include the augmentation of existing populations.
[Statement 3]: One review found that 41% of release programmes for captive-bred or head-started amphibians showed evidence of breeding in the wild for multiple generations.
[Statement 4]: One review found that 29% of release programmes for captive-bred or head-started amphibians showed some evidence of breeding.
[Statement 5]: One review found that 12% of release programmes for captive-bred or head-started amphibians showed evidence of survival following release.
[Statement 6]: Head-starting programs showed positive outcomes, with six of ten studies finding that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding frog populations.
[Statement 7]: Six of ten studies on head-starting programs found that released tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles increased populations of frogs or toads.
[Statement 8]: Two of three studies found that captive-bred toads released as tadpoles, juveniles or metamorphs established populations.
[Statement 9]: In one case, captive-bred toads released as tadpoles, juveniles or metamorphs established populations at 70% of sites.
[Statement 10]: For natterjack toads specifically, three studies found that translocated eggs, tadpoles, juveniles or adults established breeding populations at one site.
[Statement 11]: For natterjack toads specifically, three studies found that translocated eggs, tadpoles, juveniles or adults established breeding populations in 30-70% of cases.
[Statement 12]: Potential negative impacts of releasing toads include high mortality rates and low survival following release.
[Statement 13]: Studies found that survival of released captive-bred Puerto Rican crested toads was low.
[Statement 14]: Studies found that 25% of released captive-bred Puerto Rican crested toads were predated within two days of release.
[Statement 15]: Some release programs showed limited success, with one study finding that captive-bred and head-started toads did not establish populations.
[Statement 16]: Two studies found that head-started metamorphs or adults did not prevent a frog population decline.
[Statement 17]: Two studies found that head-started metamorphs or adults did not establish a breeding toad population.
[Statement 18]: For natterjack toads, one study found that translocating wild toads was more successful than releasing captive-bred toads.
[Statement 19]: For natterjack toads, translocating wild toads was particularly successful with replicated translocations.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the documented benefits and potential negative impacts of releasing captive-bred or head-started toads into the wild?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions can be taken to provide or improve shelter and refuge habitats for amphibians.
[Statement 2]: Creating artificial hibernacula or aestivation sites has shown some effectiveness for amphibians.
[Statement 3]: One study in the UK found that providing artificial hibernacula along with other terrestrial habitat management maintained populations of great crested newts.
[Statement 4]: Another UK study found that created hibernacula were used by the common frog and smooth newts.
[Statement 5]: Creating refuges for amphibians by adding coarse woody debris has shown mixed results.
[Statement 6]: Two studies in the USA and Indonesia found that adding coarse woody debris to forest floors had no effect on the number of amphibian species or overall amphibian abundance.
[Statement 7]: Adding coarse woody debris to forest floors had mixed effects on the abundance of individual amphibian species.
[Statement 8]: One study in Australia found that restoration including reintroducing coarse woody debris to the forest floor increased the number of frog species.
[Statement 9]: One UK study found that creating refugia for great crested newts, along with other interventions, maintained four populations of the newts.
[Statement 10]: Artificial refugia were used by translocated Hamilton's frogs and hellbenders.
[Statement 11]: Few of the artificial refugia used by translocated Hamilton's frogs and hellbenders were used for breeding.
[Statement 12]: In captive breeding situations, providing particular enclosure furniture for calling sites, breeding areas or egg-laying sites has proven effective.
[Statement 13]: One study in Fiji found that adding rotting logs and hollow bamboo pipes promoted egg-laying in frogs.
[Statement 14]: One study in Austria found that captive frogs started breeding when housed in enclosures with more calling, perching, and laying sites.
[Statement 15]: Providing natural substrate has been beneficial for amphibian species which do not breed in water.
[Statement 16]: Two studies found that adding a variety of substrates to enclosures promoted egg-laying in frogs.
[Statement 17]: Changing mowing regimes can help improve amphibian habitats.
[Statement 18]: One Australian study found that restoration including reduced mowing increased the numbers of frog species.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What actions can be taken to provide or improve shelter and refuge habitats for amphibians?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several factors have been found to influence the success of amphibian translocation projects.
[Statement 2]: Three global reviews and one replicated study found that 65% of amphibian translocations resulted in established breeding populations or substantial recruitment to the adult population.
[Statement 3]: One review found that translocations of over 1,000 animals were more successful.
[Statement 4]: The number of animals translocated is a key factor for success in amphibian translocation projects.
[Statement 5]: The success of amphibian translocation was not related to the source of animals (wild or captive), the life-stage of the animals, the continent, or the reason for the translocation.
[Statement 6]: Head-starting approaches can support translocation efforts for amphibians.
[Statement 7]: Six of ten studies found that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs, or juveniles established breeding populations or increased populations.
[Statement 8]: The timing of release for translocated amphibians appears to be important.
[Statement 9]: One study found that tadpoles released earlier had higher survival than those released a month later.
[Statement 10]: One study found that tadpoles released earlier metamorphosed two weeks later than those released a month later.
[Statement 11]: One review of captive-bred amphibian release programmes found that 41% showed evidence of breeding in the wild for multiple generations.
[Statement 12]: One review of captive-bred amphibian release programmes found that 29% showed some evidence of breeding.
[Statement 13]: One review of captive-bred amphibian release programmes found that 12% showed evidence of survival following release.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What factors have been found to influence the success of amphibian translocation projects?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on studies conducted in the USA, partial harvesting techniques show mixed but generally less negative effects on salamander populations compared to clearcutting.
[Statement 2]: A meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America found that partial harvest, including shelterwood harvesting, leave-tree, group harvesting and thinning, resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting.
[Statement 3]: Three studies in the USA found that compared to clearcutting, shelterwood harvesting resulted in higher, similar, or initially higher and then similar salamander abundance.
[Statement 4]: When compared to no harvesting, two of three studies found that shelterwood harvesting decreased salamander abundance and changed species composition.
[Statement 5]: Three studies in the USA found that compared to clearcutting, harvesting trees in small groups did not result in higher amphibian or salamander abundance.
[Statement 6]: Compared to no harvesting, two studies found that harvesting trees in small groups significantly decreased salamander abundance and changed species composition.
[Statement 7]: Two studies in the USA found that compared to clearcutting, leaving a low density of trees during harvest did not result in higher salamander abundance.
[Statement 8]: Compared to no harvesting, leaving a low density of trees during harvest decreased salamander abundance and changed species composition.
[Statement 9]: Salamander reproductive parameters were affected across all partial harvesting methods.
[Statement 10]: One study found that compared to unharvested plots, the proportion of female salamanders carrying eggs, eggs per female, or proportion of juveniles were similar or lower in harvested plots, including shelterwood, leave-tree, and group harvesting plots.
[Statement 11]: The effects of harvesting on salamander reproduction can depend on the species and the time since the harvest.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In the USA, how do partial harvesting techniques like shelterwood, leave-tree, and group harvesting compare in their effects on salamander populations versus clearcutting?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on available evidence from studies in the USA and UK, the observed effects of excluding livestock from ponds and streams on amphibian populations show mixed results.
[Statement 2]: In the USA, some studies found that excluding livestock from streams or ponds did not increase the numbers of amphibian species or their overall abundance.
[Statement 3]: In the USA, some studies found that excluding livestock from streams or ponds did increase larval abundance and the abundance of green frog metamorphs.
[Statement 4]: Two studies found that the abundance of green frogs and/or American toads was higher with grazing.
[Statement 5]: One study in the USA found that excluding cattle from ponds did not increase the number of eggs of Columbia spotted frogs.
[Statement 6]: One study in the USA found that excluding cattle from ponds did not increase the larval survival of Columbia spotted frogs.
[Statement 7]: A study in wet grasslands in the USA found no difference in the abundance of Yosemite toads between areas where cattle were excluded and grazed areas.
[Statement 8]: A study in the UK found that pond restoration that included livestock exclusion increased pond use by breeding natterjack toads.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What have been the observed effects of excluding livestock from ponds and streams on amphibian populations in the USA and UK?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several design and placement factors are associated with the successful use of road tunnels by migrating amphibians.
[Statement 2]: The diameter of a road tunnel affects its use by amphibians.
[Statement 3]: Wider culverts are used more by migrating amphibians.
[Statement 4]: The length of a road tunnel is an important factor for its use by amphibians.
[Statement 5]: Long culverts are avoided by migrating amphibians.
[Statement 6]: Lighting affects road tunnel use by amphibians, though the effects can be mixed.
[Statement 7]: Substrate choice is a crucial factor for road tunnel use by amphibians.
[Statement 8]: Natural substrates in road tunnels are used more by amphibians than artificial substrates.
[Statement 9]: The presence of water in road tunnels has mixed effects on their use by amphibians.
[Statement 10]: The location of a road tunnel's entrance affects its use by amphibians.
[Statement 11]: The climate within a road tunnel affects its use by amphibians.
[Statement 12]: Most successful culverts and tunnels for amphibians use barrier fencing to guide the animals to the entrances.
[Statement 13]: Barrier fencing for amphibians needs to be at least 0.6 m high to prevent frogs from climbing over the fencing.
[Statement 14]: Some species, such as treefrogs, can climb over barrier fencing.
[Statement 15]: Some common toads are able to climb over barrier fencing during breeding migrations.
[Statement 16]: One-way tunnels designed with vertical entry chutes resulted in high mortality for common toads.
[Statement 17]: Condensation deposits from steel culverts can have very high metal concentrations.
[Statement 18]: Amphibians are capable of using culverts that contain flowing water.
[Statement 19]: The use of culverts with flowing water by amphibians varies depending on the species.
[Statement 20]: Some species of salamanders rarely use culverts with flowing water.
[Statement 21]: Other salamander species use culverts with flowing water as frequently as they use dry culverts.
[Statement 22]: Installing ledges inside culverts can increase their use.
[Statement 23]: Under-road culverts equipped with ledges were used more by mammal species than culverts without ledges.
[Statement 24]: Ledges that have access ramps were used more often than ledges without access ramps.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What design and placement factors are associated with the successful use of road tunnels by migrating amphibians?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on available evidence from US forest studies, mechanical and herbicide-based methods for controlling understory vegetation show different effects on amphibians.
[Statement 2]: In the USA, studies found that understory removal using herbicide had no effect or some negative effects on amphibian abundance.
[Statement 3]: A study in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species were significantly higher in plots with mechanical understory reduction compared to plots without mechanical understory reduction.
[Statement 4]: A study in the USA found that amphibian abundance was not significantly higher in plots with mechanical understory reduction compared to those without.
[Statement 5]: Mechanical methods for controlling understory vegetation may be more favorable for maintaining amphibian species diversity compared to herbicide treatments.
[Statement 6]: In US forests, herbicide treatments showed neutral to negative effects on amphibian abundance.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In US forests, how do mechanical and herbicide-based methods for controlling understory vegetation compare in their effects on amphibians?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several legal and regulatory approaches exist to protect wild amphibian populations from development and trade threats.
[Statement 2]: Legislative regulation can be effective for protecting wild amphibian populations from trade.
[Statement 3]: Legislation to reduce trade in two frog species resulted in the recovery of over-exploited populations.
[Statement 4]: The legal protection of species shows mixed effectiveness for threats from development.
[Statement 5]: In the Netherlands and UK, the legal protection of amphibian species was not effective at protecting populations during development.
[Statement 6]: The number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued increased to over 600 in England and Wales over a 10-year period.
[Statement 7]: Habitat protection measures show some promise for protecting amphibians.
[Statement 8]: A study in the UK found that natterjack toad populations were better protected at sites with statutory habitat protection than those outside protected areas.
[Statement 9]: Results for habitat protection were mixed for some species, with common frogs increasing but common toads decreasing following pond protection during development.
[Statement 10]: A study in South Africa found that permits issued for scientific and educational use of amphibians increased from 1987 to 1990 under legislative regulation.
[Statement 11]: For broader wildlife protection, regulating wildlife harvesting has shown some success for reptile populations.
[Statement 12]: Studies have shown increased population density and average size in reptile populations following legal protection and harvest regulations.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What legal and regulatory actions are available to protect wild amphibian populations from threats like development and trade?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Adding limestone to ponds for natterjack toad conservation in the UK has shown both benefits and negative side effects.
[Statement 2]: A benefit of adding limestone to ponds was the establishment of one of three translocated populations of natterjack toads.
[Statement 3]: Adding limestone to ponds increased natterjack toad populations when combined with other species-specific habitat management.
[Statement 4]: Adding limestone to ponds temporarily increased breeding by natterjack toads.
[Statement 5]: Adding limestone to ponds resulted in the metamorphosis of natterjack toads at two of three sites.
[Statement 6]: Limestone addition to ponds increased larval and/or egg survival in some amphibian species.
[Statement 7]: A documented negative side effect of adding limestone to ponds is high tadpole mortality in natterjack toads.
[Statement 8]: A documented negative side effect of adding limestone to ponds is pond abandonment by natterjack toads.
[Statement 9]: A documented negative side effect of adding limestone to ponds is higher numbers of abnormal common frog eggs.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__For natterjack toad conservation in the UK, what are the documented benefits and negative side effects of adding lime to ponds?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence on creating or restoring terrestrial habitat connectivity for amphibian populations is extremely limited.
[Statement 2]: One before-and-after study in Italy found that restoring connectivity between two wetlands by raising a road on a viaduct significantly decreased deaths of migrating amphibians.
[Statement 3]: One before-and-after study in Australia found that retaining native vegetation corridors maintained populations of eight of 13 frog species over 20 years.
[Statement 4]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of creating habitat connectivity on amphibian populations specifically.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of maintaining, restoring or creating habitat connectivity on farmland for mammals.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of restoring or creating linear habitat features or green corridors on bat populations.
[Statement 7]: No evidence was found specifically related to hedgerows for amphibian habitat connectivity.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the state of evidence on creating or restoring terrestrial habitat connectivity, such as through hedgerows, for amphibian populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The most beneficial strategies for managing chytridiomycosis in captive amphibians are temperature treatment and antifungal treatment.
[Statement 2]: Temperature treatment for chytridiomycosis shows high success rates.
[Statement 3]: Increasing enclosure or water temperature to 30-37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 4]: Antifungal treatment is highly effective for managing chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 5]: Studies found that antifungal treatment cured or increased survival of amphibians with chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 6]: Studies testing itraconazole specifically found the antifungal medication effective at curing amphibians.
[Statement 7]: Antibacterial treatment for chytridiomycosis shows mixed results.
[Statement 8]: Chloramphenicol antibiotic treatments cured some amphibian species of chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 9]: Trimethoprim-sulfadiazine only increased survival time without curing blue-and-yellow poison dart frogs.
[Statement 10]: Immunization is considered one of the least beneficial strategies for managing chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 11]: Vaccinating mountain yellow-legged frogs with formalin-killed chytrid fungus showed no significant reduction in infection rate or mortality.
[Statement 12]: Using antifungal skin bacteria or peptides is considered one of the least beneficial strategies for managing chytridiomycosis.
[Statement 13]: Studies found no reduction in infection rate or death when adding antifungal bacteria to amphibian skin.
[Statement 14]: Antifungal treatments carry risks for amphibians.
[Statement 15]: Specific fungicides have been found to cause death or other negative side effects in amphibians.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__To manage chytridiomycosis in captive amphibians, what are the most and least beneficial treatment strategies?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Studies on releasing captive-bred toads show varied but generally positive outcomes for establishing breeding populations.
[Statement 2]: For Mallorcan midwife toads, studies found that captive-bred individuals released as tadpoles, toadlets or adults established breeding populations at 38%, 80% or 100% of sites respectively.
[Statement 3]: One study found that while predator defences were maintained, genetic diversity was reduced in captive-bred reintroduced toad populations.
[Statement 4]: Toads bred in captivity for nine or more generations showed slower tadpole development.
[Statement 5]: Toads bred in captivity for nine or more generations showed a reduction in predator defence traits.
[Statement 6]: Toads bred in captivity for nine or more generations showed decreased genetic diversity.
[Statement 7]: For some toad species, studies found that captive-bred toads released as tadpoles, juveniles or metamorphs established populations.
[Statement 8]: The success rates for establishing populations of some captive-bred toad species were 70% at some sites.
[Statement 9]: The outcomes of releasing captive-bred toads varied significantly by species.
[Statement 10]: Studies of Puerto Rican crested toads found low survival rates, with 25% of the toads being predated within two days of release.
[Statement 11]: Head-starting programs for toads showed positive results.
[Statement 12]: Studies found that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding populations or increased existing populations.
[Statement 13]: Captive breeding success rates for toads varied by species and conditions.
[Statement 14]: Various toad species have produced eggs successfully in captivity.
[Statement 15]: Studies have successfully raised captive-bred toads to tadpoles, toadlets or adults.
[Statement 16]: Two studies found that most captive-bred toads died after hatching or metamorphosis.
[Statement 17]: Breeding success for harlequin toads in captivity was challenging, with only three of five studies achieving reproduction.
[Statement 18]: Environmental factors significantly affected captive breeding outcomes for toads.
[Statement 19]: The reproductive success of captive toads was influenced by tank humidity.
[Statement 20]: Outdoor enclosures for captive toad breeding showed higher success rates than indoor tanks.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the general outcomes of releasing captive-bred toads, including species like the Mallorcan midwife toad?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several design factors are associated with the success or failure of tunnels and culverts for amphibian passage.
[Statement 2]: The diameter of tunnels and culverts significantly affects amphibian usage.
[Statement 3]: Wider culverts are used more by amphibians.
[Statement 4]: The length of tunnels and culverts impacts their effectiveness for amphibian passage.
[Statement 5]: Amphibians may avoid using long culverts.
[Statement 6]: The effect of lighting on the usage of tunnels and culverts by amphibians is mixed.
[Statement 7]: The type of substrate inside tunnels and culverts influences amphibian usage.
[Statement 8]: Amphibians use tunnels and culverts with natural substrates more than those with artificial ones.
[Statement 9]: The presence of water in tunnels and culverts has mixed effects on amphibian usage.
[Statement 10]: The location of a tunnel or culvert entrance affects amphibian usage patterns.
[Statement 11]: The climate within a tunnel influences amphibian usage.
[Statement 12]: Barrier fencing is crucial for guiding amphibians to the entrances of tunnels and culverts.
[Statement 13]: The majority of effective culverts and tunnels for amphibian passage had barrier fencing.
[Statement 14]: A study found that amphibian road deaths decreased only when barrier fencing was also installed with culverts.
[Statement 15]: Barrier fencing must be at least 0.6 meters high to prevent green frogs and leopard frogs from climbing over the fencing.
[Statement 16]: Some amphibians like treefrogs can climb over barrier fencing.
[Statement 17]: During breeding migrations, 10% of common toads can climb over barrier fencing.
[Statement 18]: Certain design features in amphibian passages result in failure.
[Statement 19]: One-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes resulted in high mortality of common toads.
[Statement 20]: Condensation deposits from steel culverts had very high metal concentrations.
[Statement 21]: Studies of culverts with flowing water show mixed results for amphibian usage.
[Statement 22]: Some culverts with flowing water are used by amphibians, while others are rarely used or not used at all.
[Statement 23]: Thousands of amphibians were still killed on roads even where culverts were installed for mitigation.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__For road mitigation projects, what design factors are associated with the success or failure of tunnels and culverts for amphibian passage?
